content:
Parkour

Parkour (French: [paʁkuʁ]) is a training discipline using movement that developed from military obstacle course training. Practitioners, called tracers or traceurs, aim to get from one point to another in a complex environment, without assistive equipment and in the fastest and most efficient way possible. Parkour includes running, climbing, swinging, vaulting, jumping, plyometrics, rolling, quadrupedal movement (crawling) and other movements as deemed most suitable for the situation (not to be confused with freerunning).{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.flowjournal.org/2010/05/from-%E2%80%9Cplay-to-display%E2%80%9D-parkour-as-media-mimetics-or-nature-reclamation-matthew-ferrari-university-of-massachusetts-amherst/", "title": "From 'Play to Display': Parkour as Media-Mimetics or Nature Reclamation?", "last": "Ferrari", "first": "Matthew", "date": "7 May 2010", "urlstatus": "live", "work": "FlowTV, vol 11, lokaliseret den 01-04-2011 p\u00e5"}{"citetype": "journal", "year": "2011", "title": "Parkour and the Built Environment: Spatial Practices and the Plasticity of School Buildings", "url": "http://journal.jctonline.org/index.php/jct/article/view/126", "journal": "Journal of Curriculum Theorizing", "volume": "27", "issue": "3", "page": "209", "last": "De Feitas", "first": "Elizabeth"} Parkour's development from military training gives it some aspects of a non-combative martial art.
Parkour is an activity that can be practiced alone or with others and is usually carried out in urban spaces, though it can be done anywhere.{"citetype": "book", "last1": "Rawlinson", "first1": "Christopher", "last2": "Guaralda", "first2": "Mirko", "date": "11 September 2012", "title": "In Out of Control: 8th International Conference on Design and Emotion", "url": "http://eprints.qut.edu.au/51313/", "location": "Central Saint Martins College of Arts and Design, London", "accessdate": "16 March 2013", "contribution": "Chaos and creativity of play: designing emotional engagement in public spaces"}{"citetype": "journal", "doi ": "10.1007/s00146-010-0294-2", "title ": "Nice-looking obstacles: Parkour as urban practice of deterritorialization", "journal ": "AI & Society", "volume ": "26", "issue ": "2", "pages ": "143\u2013152", "year ": "2010", "last1 ": "Brunner", "first1 ": "C.", "url ": "http://doc.rero.ch/record/312807/files/146_2010_Article_294.pdf"} Parkour involves seeing one's environment in a new way, and imagining the potential for navigating it by movement around, across, through, over and under its features.[8][9]
Parkour as a type of movement was established by the French David Belle in 1988{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkourgenerations.com/parkour-history/", "title": "Parkour History", "date": "22 August 2014", "publisher": "Parkour Generations", "accessdate": "2 December 2015"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYwQLvIkQ88", "title": "Interview with David Belle", "accessdate": "2 December 2015"}, however the practice of similar movements in various communities around the world leads to discuss the relevance of such an attribution {"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}. The discipline was popularised in the late 1990s and 2000s through films, documentaries, video games and advertisements featuring the Yamakasi.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}{"citetype": "book", "lastauthoramp": "yes", "title": "PARKOUR \u2013 From the origins to the practise", "ref": "Belle", "author1": "Belle, David", "author2": "Perri\u00e9re, Charles"}{"citetype": "journal", "last1": "Atkinson", "first1": "M.", "year": "2009", "title": "Parkour, Anarcho-Environmentalism, and Poiesis", "journal": "Journal of Sport & Social Issues", "volume": "33", "issue": "2", "pages": "169\u2013194", "doi": "10.1177/0193723509332582"}

Etymology
The word parkour derives from parcours du combattant (obstacle course), the classic obstacle course method of military training proposed by Georges Hébert.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.pawa.fr/Welcome/welcome.html", "title": "English welcome \u2014 Parkour Worldwide Association", "last": "Russell", "first": "Matthew", "accessdate": "12 May 2007", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050508021450/http://www.pawa.fr/Welcome/welcome.html", "archivedate": "8 May 2005"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=3937", "title": "PAWA statement on Freerunning", "date": "23 February 2006", "accessdate": "12 May 2007", "urlstatus": "dead", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20070927193626/http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=3937", "archivedate": "27 September 2007"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=5481", "title": "The name Parkour, simple question", "accessdate": "12 April 2007", "urlstatus": "dead", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20070927193447/http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=5481", "archivedate": "27 September 2007"} Raymond Belle used the term "les parcours" to encompass all of his training including climbing, jumping, running, balancing, and the other methods he undertook in his personal athletic advancement.[18] His son, David, further developed his father's methods and achieved success as a stuntman, and one day on a film set showed his 'Speed Air Man' video to Hubert Koundé. Koundé suggested he change the "c" of "parcours" to a "k" because it was stronger and more dynamic, and to remove the silent "s" for the same reason, forming "parkour".[19]
A practitioner of parkour is called a traceur, with the feminine form being traceuse.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.flowjournal.org/2010/05/from-%E2%80%9Cplay-to-display%E2%80%9D-parkour-as-media-mimetics-or-nature-reclamation-matthew-ferrari-university-of-massachusetts-amherst/", "title": "From 'Play to Display': Parkour as Media-Mimetics or Nature Reclamation?", "last": "Ferrari", "first": "Matthew", "date": "7 May 2010", "urlstatus": "live", "work": "FlowTV, vol 11, lokaliseret den 01-04-2011 p\u00e5"} They are nouns derived from the French verb tracer, which normally means "to trace", as in "tracing a path", in reference to drawing.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.cnrtl.fr/lexicographie/tracer?", "title": "Portail lexical \u2014 D\u00e9finition de tracer", "language": "French", "accessdate": "28 August 2007"} The verb tracer used familiarly means: "to hurry up".[21] The term traceur was originally the name of a parkour group headed by David Belle which included Sébastien Foucan and Stéphane Vigroux.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_d1AxUPPcF8", "title": "An Interview With Stephane Vigroux", "date": "27 January 2009", "publisher": "YouTube", "accessdate": "22 May 2014"}
A jam refers to a meeting of traceurs, involving training lasting anywhere from hours to several days, often with people from different cities. The first parkour jam was organised in July 2002 by Romain Drouet, with a dozen people including Sébastien Foucan and Stéphane Vigroux.

Georges Hébert
In Western Europe, a forerunner of parkour was developed by French naval officer Georges Hébert, who before World War I promoted athletic skill based on the models of indigenous tribes he had met in Africa.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "title": "Georges Hebert and the Natural Method of Physical Culture", "accessdate": "2 July 2013", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050323090031/http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "archivedate": "23 March 2005", "author": "Artful Dodger"} He noted, "their bodies were splendid, flexible, nimble, skillful, enduring, and resistant but yet they had no other tutor in gymnastics but their lives in nature."{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "title": "Georges Hebert and the Natural Method of Physical Culture", "accessdate": "2 July 2013", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050323090031/http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "archivedate": "23 March 2005", "author": "Artful Dodger"} His rescue efforts during the 1902 eruption of Mount Pelée on Saint-Pierre, Martinique, reinforced his belief that athletic skill must be combined with courage and altruism.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "title": "Georges Hebert and the Natural Method of Physical Culture", "accessdate": "2 July 2013", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050323090031/http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "archivedate": "23 March 2005", "author": "Artful Dodger"} Hébert became a physical education tutor at the college of Reims in France. Hébert set up a "méthode naturelle" (natural method) session consisting of ten fundamental groups: walking, running, jumping, quadrupedal movement, climbing, balancing, throwing, lifting, self-defence and swimming. These were intended to develop "the three main forces": energetic (willpower, courage, coolness, and firmness), moral (benevolence, assistance, honour, and honesty) and physical (muscles and breath).{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://perso.orange.fr/le.parkour/france/medias/page3.html", "title": "Georges H\u00e9bert \u2014 la methode naturalle", "publisher": "INSEP \u2014 Mus\u00e9e de la Marine", "language": "French", "format": "JPG", "accessdate": "22 September 2007", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20060718150740/http://perso.orange.fr/le.parkour/france/medias/page3.html", "archivedate": "18 July 2006"} During World War I and World War II, teaching continued to expand, becoming the standard system of French military education and training. Inspired by Hébert, a Swiss architect developed a "parcours du combattant"{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/04/16/070416fa_fact_wilkinson?currentPage=all", "title": "No Obstacles", "last": "Wilkinson", "first": "Alec", "date": "16 April 2007", "accessdate": "14 October 2007", "work": "[[The New Yorker]]"}—military obstacle course—the first of the courses that are now standard in military training and which led to the development of civilian fitness trails and confidence courses.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "title": "Georges Hebert and the Natural Method of Physical Culture", "accessdate": "2 July 2013", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20050323090031/http://www.urbanfreeflow.com/articles/methode_naturelle.htm", "archivedate": "23 March 2005", "author": "Artful Dodger"}

Raymond and David Belle
Born in 1939 in Vietnam, Raymond Belle was the son of a French physician and Vietnamese mother. During the First Indochina War, his father died and he was separated from his mother, after which he was sent to a military orphanage in Da Lat at the age of 7. He took it upon himself to train harder and longer than everyone else in order never to be a victim. At night, when everyone else was asleep, he would be outside running or climbing trees. He would use the military obstacle courses in secret, and also created courses of his own that tested his endurance, strength, and flexibility. Doing this enabled him not only to survive the hardships he experienced during his childhood, but also eventually to thrive. After the Battle of Dien Bien Phu in 1954, he returned to France and remained in military education until the age of 19, when he joined the Paris Fire Brigade, a French Army unit.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}[26]{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.net/modules/articles/item.php?itemid=3", "title": "Raymond Belle's biography", "date": "17 February 2006", "publisher": "Parkour.NET", "accessdate": "29 November 2007", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20060217200929/http://parkour.net/modules/articles/item.php?itemid=3", "archivedate": "17 February 2006", "work": "Original French biography sourced from 'Allo Dix-Huit', the magazine of the Parisian pompiers."}
Raymond's son, David Belle, was born in 1973. He experimented with gymnastics and athletics but became increasingly disaffected with both school and the sports clubs. As he got older, he claims to have to read (as-yet-unconfirmed) newspaper clippings that told of his father's exploits and was increasingly curious about what had enabled his father to accomplish these feats. Through conversations with his father, he realised that what he really wanted was a means to develop skills that would be useful to him in life, rather than just training to kick a ball or perform moves in a padded, indoor environment.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}[18]
Through   conversations with his father, David learned about this way of training that his father called "parcours". He heard his father talk of the many repetitions he had done in order to find the best way of doing things. He learned  that for his father, training was not a game but something vital which enabled him to survive and to protect the people he cared about. David realised that this was what he had been searching for, and so he began training in the same way. After a time, he found it far more important to him than schooling and he gave up his other commitments to focus all his time on his training.[18]

Yamakasi
David initially trained on his own, and after moving to Lisses, found other young men (including his cousins) who had similar desires, and they began to train together.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://davidbelle.com/biography-eng/", "title": "Actor David Belle Biography", "publisher": "David Belle", "accessdate": "22 May 2014", "urlstatus": "dead", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20141020053729/http://davidbelle.com/biography-eng/", "archivedate": "20 October 2014"} The group eventually included David Belle, Sébastien Foucan, Châu Belle Dinh, Williams Belle, Yann Hnautra, Laurent Piemontesi, Guylain N'Guba Boyeke, Malik Diouf, and Charles Perrière.

Discipline
The group put themselves through challenges that forced them to find the physical and mental strength to succeed. Examples included training without food or water, or sleeping on the floor without a blanket, to learn to endure the cold.[28] For example, no one in the group was permitted to be late for training, as it would hold back the whole group. If any member completed a challenge, everyone else had to do the same thing.[29] During their training no one was allowed to complain or be negative. Few excuses were allowed. For instance, if someone claimed that his shoes were too worn out in order to make a jump, he had to do it anyway, even if it meant doing the jump barefoot.[30] At the same time, everyone was required to have knowledge of their own limits.[31]
Respecting one's health and physical well-being was one of the foundations of the group. If any member hurt himself during or after the execution of a movement, the movement was deemed a failure. A movement executed only once was not considered an achievement; only with repetition was the challenge complete. Every movement had to be repeated at least ten times in a row without the traceur having to push his limits or sustaining any injury. If any mistake was made by any traceur in the group everyone had to start all over again.[29]
Humility was an important principle.[31] No traceur was allowed to feel superior over someone else, for example by executing a movement only to show off in front of someone who could not perform the movement. If any traceur in the group claimed that he had completed a difficult and dangerous challenge that should not be attempted unaided, he had to prove his claims by doing the challenge again. Anyone who lied violated the principle of humility.[29]
To join the group, new members had to be recommended by an existing member and then pass tests to evaluate their motivation for joining.[30] Despite the huge emphasis on the collective, each traceur had to progress and develop independently — "to create the means to be yourself"[32] — and there was a complete trust within the group.[31] Every traceur was to encourage the others and show confidence through their behaviour.[33] If a member violated the principles, the group could meet without the offending person to discuss various punishments. Anyone deemed unsuitable could be temporarily or even permanently banned from the group in order to uphold its disciplines and values.[34]
The group also drew influence from Asian cultures, notably the acrobatic antics of Jackie Chan in his Hong Kong action films,{"citetype": "book", "last1": "Stratford", "first1": "Elaine", "date": "2014", "title": "Geographies, Mobilities, and Rhythms over the Life-Course: Adventures in the Interval", "url": "https://books.google.com/books?id=d4yLBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA79", "publisher": "[[Routledge]]", "page": "79", "isbn": "9781135117429"}{"citetype": "book", "last1": "Hunt", "first1": "Leon", "last2": "Wing-Fai", "first2": "Leung", "date": "2010", "title": "East Asian Cinemas: Exploring Transnational Connections on Film", "url": "https://books.google.com/books?id=pzgBAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA229", "publisher": "[[I.B. Tauris]]", "isbn": "9780857712271"} as well as the philosophy of Bruce Lee.{"citetype": "news", "title": "Parkour History", "url": "https://parkourgenerations.com/parkour-history/", "work": "Parkour Generations", "accessdate": "13 March 2019"}

Name and split
In 1997, David Belle's brother Jean-François invited the group to perform for the public in a firefighter show in Paris.[38] For the performance, the group named themselves Yamakasi, from the Congolese Lingala ya makási, meaning strong in one's person, or "strong man, strong spirit". Sébastien Foucan also invented a name for what they were doing: "l'art du déplacement" (French for "the art of movement").[38] The firefighter performance caused both positive and negative attention. Some members of the group were concerned how the public would view their discipline since the performance did not demonstrate all aspects of it, such as their hard training and their values and ethics. Jean-François also sent pictures and video of the group to a French TV programme, and the popularity of parkour began to increase. A series of television programmes in various countries subsequently featured video footage of the group, and they began to get more requests for performances. During this time, conflicting interests arose within the group. Sébastien Foucan wanted to teach more rather than to train more, and David Belle had the ambition to become an actor. David and Sébastien chose to leave the group, and used the name "parkour" to describe their activity (see § Etymology above). The seven remaining Yamakasi members continued to use the term l'art du déplacement{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}[39] (see § Derivative terminologies and disciplines below).

Organizations
National parkour organizations include the World Freerunning and Parkour Federation, established in 2007, who have worked with MTV to produce Parkour related shows.[40]
International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) added parkour as one of their disciplines in 2017, receiving lots of opposition.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.accessparkour.com/fig-gate-the-story-so-far/", "title": "Fig-Gate: The Great Parkour Scandal", "date": "11 May 2017", "publisher": "accessparkour.com"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1051013/denmark-add-voice-to-opposition-of-figs-move-into-parkour", "title": "Denmark add voice to opposition of FIG's move into parkour", "date": "1 June 2017", "publisher": "insidethegames.biz"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1053647/parkour-earth-officially-becomes-sports-international-federation-as-fig-row-continues", "title": "Parkour Earth officially launches as FIG row continues", "date": "4 August 2017", "publisher": "insidethegames.biz"} Programme includes Speed-Run (Sprint) and Freestyle. They launched FIG Parkour World Cup in 2018, first event was held on 6–8 April 2018.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.gymnastics.sport/site/news/displaynews.php?idNews=2017", "title": "7 days to go till first FIG Parkour World Cup", "date": "30 March 2018", "publisher": "[[International Gymnastics Federation]]"} The 1st Parkour World Championships is scheduled to take place at Hiroshima, Japan, on 3–5 April 2020.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.gymnastics.sport/site/news/displaynews.php?idNews=2057", "title": "Main decisions from the 18th FIG Council in Istanbul", "date": "14 May 2018", "publisher": "[[International Gymnastics Federation]]"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.gymnastics.sport/site/news/displaynews.php?idNews=2586", "title": "Hiroshima to host 1st Parkour World Championships in 2020"} Parkour will also make its World Games debut at the 2021 World Games.[47]

Philosophy
According to Williams Belle, the philosophies and theories behind parkour are an integral aspect of the art, one that many non-practitioners have never been exposed to. Belle says he trains people because he wants it "to be alive" and "for people to use it".[48] Châu Belle explains it is a "type of freedom" or "kind of expression"; that parkour is "only a state of mind" rather than a set of actions, and that it is about overcoming and adapting to mental and emotional obstacles as well as physical barriers.[48] Traceur Dylan Baker says, "Parkour also influences one's thought processes by enhancing self-confidence and critical thinking skills that allow one to overcome everyday physical and mental obstacles".[48]{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.thelantern.com/2.1347/students-on-campus-are-mastering-parkour-an-art-of-self-awareness-and-body-control-1.74990", "title": "Students on campus are mastering parkour, an art of self-awareness and body control", "last": "Mai", "first": "Jeffy", "date": "14 April 2008", "accessdate": "19 April 2008", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20100925061659/http://www.thelantern.com/2.1347/students-on-campus-are-mastering-parkour-an-art-of-self-awareness-and-body-control-1.74990", "archivedate": "25 September 2010"}[50] A study by Neuropsychiatrie de l'Enfance et de l'Adolescence (Neuropsychiatry of Childhood and Adolescence) in France found traceurs seek more excitement and leadership situations than gymnasts do.{"citetype": "journal", "doi ": "10.1016/j.neurenf.2007.02.001", "title ": "La pratique du parkour chez les adolescents des banlieues: Entre recherche de sensation et renforcement narcissique", "journal ": "Neuropsychiatrie de l'Enfance et de l'Adolescence", "volume ": "55", "issue ": "3", "pages ": "154\u2013159", "year ": "2007", "last1 ": "Cazenave", "first1 ": "N."}
Academic research on parkour has tended to describe how parkour provides a novel way of interacting with the urban environment that challenges the use and meaning of urban space, metropolitan life, and embodiment.{"citetype": "journal", "date": "30 July 2012", "title": "New Media Technologies in Lifestyle Sport", "url": "https://www.academia.edu/1821623", "accessdate": "8 September 2013", "author1": "Gilchrist, Paul", "author2": "Wheaton, Belinda", "conference": "Digital Media Sport: Technology and Power in the Network Society", "editor": "Hutchins/Rowe"}
A newer convention of parkour philosophy has been the idea of "human reclamation".{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkournorthamerica.com/plugins/content/content.php?content.17", "title": "Two Theories on Parkour Philosophy", "date": "7 September 2007", "publisher": "Parkour North America", "accessdate": "16 April 2008", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20120712091605/http://parkournorthamerica.com/plugins/content/content.php?content.17", "archivedate": "12 July 2012"} Andy Tran of Urban Evolution clarifies it as "a means of reclaiming what it means to be a human being. It teaches us to move using the natural methods that we should have learned from infancy. It teaches us to touch the world and interact with it, instead of being sheltered by it."{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkournorthamerica.com/plugins/content/content.php?content.17", "title": "Two Theories on Parkour Philosophy", "date": "7 September 2007", "publisher": "Parkour North America", "accessdate": "16 April 2008", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20120712091605/http://parkournorthamerica.com/plugins/content/content.php?content.17", "archivedate": "12 July 2012"} Another traceur[who?] writes, "It is as much as a part of truly learning the physical art as well as being able to master the movements, it gives you the ability to overcome your fears and pains and reapply this to life as you must be able to control your mind in order to master the art of parkour."{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.urban-discipline.com/parkourhistory.htm", "title": "Parkour History", "accessdate": "5 January 2015", "work": "Urban discipline"}

Competition
A campaign was started on 1 May 2007 by the Parkour.NET portal to preserve parkour's philosophy against sports competition and rivalry.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=9539", "title": "Keeping parkour rivalry-free : JOIN IN !", "date": "1 May 2007", "publisher": "Parkour.NET", "accessdate": "11 May 2007"}{"citetype": "news", "last1": "Bignell", "first1": "Paul", "last2": "Sharp", "first2": "Rob", "date": "22 April 2007", "title": "'Jumped-up' plan to stage world competition sees free runners falling out", "url": "http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article2472154.ece", "urlstatus": "dead", "work": "The Independent", "location": "London", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20080101230324/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article2472154.ece", "archivedate": "1 January 2008"} In the words of Erwan Le Corre: "Competition pushes people to fight against others for the satisfaction of a crowd and/or the benefits of a few business people by changing its mindset. Parkour is unique and cannot be a competitive sport unless it ignores its altruistic core of self-development. If parkour becomes a sport, it will be hard to seriously teach and spread parkour as a non-competitive activity. And a new sport will be spread that may be called parkour, but that won't hold its philosophical essence anymore."{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=9539", "title": "Keeping parkour rivalry-free : JOIN IN !", "date": "1 May 2007", "publisher": "Parkour.NET", "accessdate": "11 May 2007"} Red Bull's sponsored athlete for parkour, Ryan Doyle, has said, "Sometimes people ask, 'Who is the best at parkour?' and it is because they don't understand what Parkour is; 'Who is the best?' is what you would say to a sport, and parkour is not a sport, it is an art, it's a discipline. That's like saying, 'What's the best song in the world?'"{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z1NzOqfW7z4", "title": "Ryan Doyle \u2013 Parkour Training Jam", "publisher": "YouTube", "accessdate": "22 May 2014"} This seems to be a highly consensual opinion of many professional traceurs who view parkour as a style of life more than a set of tricks, as has been popularised by YouTube and most media exposure.[citation needed]

David Belle
In his 2009 book "Parkour", David Belle stressed that the most important aspect of parkour is not the physical movements, but rather the practitioner's mentality and understanding of its principles. "When young trainees come to see me and give me videos telling me to check out what they are doing, I just take the tape and throw it away. What I'm interested in is what the guy's got in his head, if he has self-confidence, if he masters the technique, if he has understood the principles of parkour. I just can't deal with guys who do Parkour because they saw videos on the Internet and thought it was kinda cool and want to do even better."[58] Further, he states the importance of traceurs being aware of their abilities and limitations, and developing in their own way. "When a young person asks me: 'Can you show me how to do this?' I simply answer: "No, I am going to show you how I do it. Then, you'll have to learn with your own technique, your own way of moving, your style, your abilities and your limitations. You are going to learn to be yourself, not someone else."[59]
The philosophy of parkour has been compared to that of martial arts.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.worldwidejam.tv/db.bl.jam.parkour.html", "title": "Bruce Lee and the Philosophy of Parkour", "last": "Green", "first": "Rob", "publisher": "WorldWideJam.tv", "accessdate": "1 February 2011"} In an interview with The New Yorker, David Belle acknowledges the influence: "There's a quote by Bruce Lee that's my motto: 'There are no limits. There are plateaus, but you must not stay there, you must go beyond them. A man must constantly exceed his level.' If you're not better than you were the day before, then what are you doing—what's the point?".{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/04/16/070416fa_fact_wilkinson?currentPage=all", "title": "No Obstacles", "last": "Wilkinson", "first": "Alec", "date": "16 April 2007", "accessdate": "14 October 2007", "work": "[[The New Yorker]]"} In an interview with the press, Belle explained that parkour is a training method for warriors. "So many people try to train easy 'Come do parkour! It's really cool!' But if tomorrow I made you do real training, you would end up crying. That's what you need to know: you are going to cry, you are going to bleed and you are going to sweat like never before."[61] In his book, Belle also quotes his father Raymond: "If two roads open up before you, always take the most difficult one. Because you know you can travel the easy one."[62]
Belle is an influential proponent of discipline and control in parkour, saying, "Precision is all about being measured," and going on to describe parkour as an art that requires huge amounts of repetition and practice to master.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUeHrPazTtY", "title": "David Belle \u2013 Parkour", "date": "16 July 2011", "publisher": "YouTube", "accessdate": "22 May 2014"} "With parkour, I often say, 'Once is never'. In other words, someone can manage a jump one time but it does not mean anything. It can be luck or chance. When you make a jump, you have to do it at least three times to be sure you can actually do it. It's an unavoidable rule. Do it the hard way and stop lying to yourself. When you come for training, you have to train. Even if it means doing the same jump fifty or a hundred times."[59] To its founder, parkour is a method of self-refinement, used for learning to control and focus oneself.

Movement
While there is no official list of "moves" in parkour, the style in which practitioners move often sets them apart from others,{"citetype": "journal", "year": "2011", "title": "Parkour and the Built Environment: Spatial Practices and the Plasticity of School Buildings", "url": "http://journal.jctonline.org/index.php/jct/article/view/126", "journal": "Journal of Curriculum Theorizing", "volume": "27", "issue": "3", "page": "209", "last": "De Feitas", "first": "Elizabeth"} and there are a number of movements considered fundamental.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkourgenerations.com/parkour-history/", "title": "Parkour History", "date": "22 August 2014", "publisher": "Parkour Generations", "accessdate": "2 December 2015"} Some examples of common movements are:[64]{"citetype": "journal", "doi ": "10.1016/j.injury.2006.04.119", "pmid ": "16806217", "title ": "Paediatric fractures sustained in Parkour (free running)", "journal ": "Injury", "volume ": "37", "issue ": "8", "pages ": "795\u2013797", "year ": "2006", "last1 ": "McLean", "first1 ": "C. R.", "last2 ": "Houshian", "first2 ": "S.", "last3 ": "Pike", "first3 ": "J."}

Equipment
Parkour is practiced without equipment of any kind. Though, items such as bars, walls, and boxes, are used. Practitioners normally train wearing light, non-restrictive casual clothing.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.americanparkour.com/content/view/50/237/", "title": "What Should I Wear for parkour?", "date": "6 November 2005", "publisher": "americanparkour.com", "accessdate": "21 April 2007", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20090203212658/http://www.americanparkour.com/content/view/50/237/", "archivedate": "3 February 2009"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkourvisions.org/resources/parents-faq.pdf", "title": "Is there any equipment cost, membership fee, or exclusive conditions required for my child to do Parkour?", "publisher": "washingtonparkour.com", "accessdate": "4 April 2008", "year ": "2008"} Traceurs who wear gloves are rare—bare hands are considered better for grip and tactile feedback.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://articles.herald-mail.com/2009-09-28/news/25176213_1_parkour-cross-country-jfk-50-mile", "title": "Parkour: All in a day's training", "last": "Arnold", "first": "Tiffany", "date": "28 September 2009", "accessdate": "25 July 2010", "urlstatus": "dead", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20140203143705/http://articles.herald-mail.com/2009-09-28/news/25176213_1_parkour-cross-country-jfk-50-mile", "archivedate": "3 February 2014", "work": "[[Herald Mail]]"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.thenational.ae/article/20090223/LIFE/125121212/-1/SPORT", "title": "You might as well jump", "last": "Money-Coutts", "first": "Sophia", "date": "23 February 2009", "publisher": "Abu Dhabi Media Company", "accessdate": "25 July 2010", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20090226064531/http://www.thenational.ae/article/20090223/LIFE/125121212/1196/TRAVEL", "archivedate": "26 February 2009", "work": "[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]"} Light running shoes with good grip and flexibility are encouraged because they allow for more natural and fluid movements. Practitioners often use minimalist shoes, sometimes as a progression to bare feet, for better sensitivity and balance, while others prefer more cushioning for better absorption of impacts from large jumps.{"citetype": "news", "date": "2017-06-11", "title": "10 Best Parkour Shoes (2020) \u2013 Freerunning Shoes Reviewed", "url": "https://parkourshoesguide.com/", "urlstatus": "live", "work": "ParkourShoesGuide", "language": "en-US", "accessdate": "2017-06-19"} Barefoot training is done by some for movement competency without gear—David Belle noted that "bare feet are the best shoes."{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QMw3q3NjqRk", "title": "David Belle \u2014 Parkour simples", "date": "16 March 2007", "publisher": "YouTube", "accessdate": "7 July 2007"} Various sneaker manufacturers have developed shoes specifically for parkour and freerunning. Many other companies around the world have started offering clothing targeted at parkour.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.knowobstacles.com", "title": "Know Obstacles", "accessdate": "12 May 2014"}

Trespassing
Parkour is not widely practiced in dedicated public facilities. Although efforts are being made to create places for it, many traceurs do not like the idea, as it is contradictory to parkour's values of adaptation, creativity, and freedom.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.miramar.usmc.mil/newspage175.htm", "title": "American Parkour HotSpots Contest", "date": "21 May 2008", "accessdate": "13 June 2008", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20090414060418/http://www.miramar.usmc.mil/newspage175.htm", "archivedate": "14 April 2009"} Traceurs practice parkour in both rural and urban areas such as gyms, parks, playgrounds, offices, and abandoned structures. Concerns have been raised regarding trespassing, damage of property,[75] and use of inappropriate places such as cemeteries.{"citetype": "news", "date": "6 May 2008", "title": "Gravestone vaulting teenagers condemned over YouTube stunt", "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/2079539/Gravestone-vaulting-teenagers-condemned-over-YouTube-stunt.html", "work": "The Daily Telegraph", "location": "London", "accessdate": "13 June 2008", "last": "Gammell", "first": "Caroline"} Many parkour organizations around the globe support the Leave No Trace initiative, an urban version of the outdoor conservation ethic created by the Seattle nonprofit Parkour Visions in 2008, promoting safety, respect for the spaces used and their other users, and sometimes includes picking up rubbish to leave areas in better condition than they were found.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkourvisions.org/projects/leave-no-trace/", "title": "Leave No Trace Campaign (practice policy)", "accessdate": "18 April 2016", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20120929092640/http://parkourvisions.org/projects/leave-no-trace/", "archivedate": "29 September 2012"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://verticalfloormag.com/?p=72", "title": "Without a Trace", "last": "Bafford", "first": "Tenedra", "date": "June 2013", "accessdate": "18 April 2016", "work": "Vertical Floor Magazine"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://nzparkour.co.nz/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/NZ-Parkour-Vision-and-Values.pdf", "title": "New Zealand Parkour Vision and Values", "last": "Puddle", "first": "Damien", "date": "23 July 2014", "accessdate": "18 April 2016"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkour.uga.edu/", "title": "Parkour at UGA", "last": "Hansen", "first": "Jimmy", "date": "1 March 2011", "accessdate": "6 June 2011"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://americanparkour.com/component/content/6562?task=view", "title": "American Parkour leaves Meridian Park when asked during national jam", "website": "American Parkour", "accessdate": "7 November 2015", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20130927125033/http://americanparkour.com/component/content/6562?task=view", "archivedate": "27 September 2013"}

Injuries and deaths
Concerns have been raised by law enforcement and fire and rescue teams of the risk in jumping off high buildings.{"citetype": "news", "date": "5 April 2008", "title": "Student Stuntmen", "url": "http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1607235,00.html", "work": "[[Time (magazine)|Time]]", "accessdate": "13 June 2008", "last": "Rawe", "first": "Julie"} They argue that practitioners are needlessly risking damage to both themselves and rooftops by practicing at height, with police forces calling for practitioners to stay off the rooftops.[75]{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/suttonnews/display.var.2166130.0.youths_on_roofs.php", "title": "Youths on Roofs", "date": "2 April 2008", "accessdate": "9 August 2009", "work": "Your Local Guardian"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.schriever.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123100262", "title": "Parkour growing by leaps and bounds", "last": "Branum", "first": "Don", "date": "2 June 2008", "accessdate": "27 June 2008"} Some practitioners of parkour agree that such behaviour should be discouraged.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/suttonnews/display.var.2166130.0.youths_on_roofs.php", "title": "Youths on Roofs", "date": "2 April 2008", "accessdate": "9 August 2009", "work": "Your Local Guardian"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.americanparkour.com/content/view/2364/1/", "title": "Terrible Representation of Parkour and Freerunning", "date": "13 June 2008", "accessdate": "13 June 2008", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20080612003334/http://www.americanparkour.com/content/view/2364/1/", "archivedate": "12 June 2008"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/running-through-life-the-parkour-way/a-1701098", "title": "Running Through Life the Parkour Way", "last": "Comenetz", "first": "Jacob", "date": "9 June 2005", "publisher": "Deutsche Welle", "accessdate": "9 August 2009"}[87]
Because parkour philosophy is about learning to control oneself in interaction with the environment, many parkour experts tend to view serious physical injury as a deviation from true parkour[clarify]. Daniel Ilabaca, co-founder of the World Parkour and Freerunning Federation, said "Thinking you're going to fail at something gives you a higher risk of doing just that. Committing to something you're thinking or knowing you will land gives you a higher chance of landing or completing the task."{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.beachcombermb.com/opinions/2012/01/27/parkour-legends-daniel-ilabaca-tim-shieff-and-oleg-vorslov/", "title": "The Beachcomber : Parkour Legends: Daniel Ilabaca, Tim Shieff, and Oleg Vorslov", "date": "17 March 2013", "publisher": "Beachcombermb.com", "accessdate": "22 May 2014", "urlstatus": "dead", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20130807001610/http://www.beachcombermb.com/opinions/2012/01/27/parkour-legends-daniel-ilabaca-tim-shieff-and-oleg-vorslov/", "archivedate": "7 August 2013", "df": "dmy-all"} On biomechanical grounds, a single study found that certain parkour landing techniques may lead to lower landing forces and loads in comparison with traditional sport technique.{"citetype": "journal", "pmid ": "24149735", "pmc ": "3761764", "year ": "2013", "last1 ": "Puddle", "first1 ": "D. L.", "title ": "Ground reaction forces and loading rates associated with parkour and traditional drop landing techniques", "journal ": "Journal of Sports Science & Medicine", "volume ": "12", "issue ": "1", "pages ": "122\u20139", "last2 ": "Maulder", "first2 ": "P. S."} In a survey of parkour-related emergency department visits in the United States between 2009 and 2015, most injuries were reportedly caused by landing or from striking objects.{"citetype": "journal", "last1": "Rossheim", "first1": "ME", "last2": "Stephenson", "first2": "CJ", "date": "October 2017", "title": "Parkour injuries presenting to United States emergency departments, 2009-2015.", "journal": "The American Journal of Emergency Medicine", "volume": "35", "issue": "10", "pages": "1503\u20131505", "doi": "10.1016/j.ajem.2017.04.040", "pmid": "28455090"}
American traceur Mark Toorock said injuries are rare "because participants rely not on what they can't control – wheels or the icy surfaces of snowboarding and skiing – but their own hands and feet," but Lanier Johnson, executive director of the American Sports Medicine Institute, noted that many of the injuries are not reported.{"citetype": "news", "date": "8 January 2008", "title": "Jump First, Ask Questions Later", "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/08/AR2008010803471_4.html", "work": "[[The Washington Post]]", "accessdate": "19 April 2008", "first": "Colin", "last": "Bane"}

Impact
Initially featured in films of French director/producer Luc Besson, parkour was first introduced to the British public by the BBC One TV channel trailer Rush Hour in April 2002. It featured David Belle leaping across London's rooftops from his office to home, in an attempt to catch his favourite BBC programme,{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2002/04_april/11/rush_hour.shtml", "title": "Unmissable new campaign for BBC ONE", "date": "11 April 2002", "accessdate": "2 December 2015", "work": "BBC Press Office"} and captured the imagination of many viewers, especially when they learned no special effects or wires were used.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1939106.stm", "title": "BBC film's rooftop stunts 'real'", "date": "19 April 2002", "accessdate": "2 December 2015", "work": "BBC News"} This advertisement, along with others for Coca-Cola, Nike, and Toyota, had a large-scale impact on public awareness of parkour.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://parkourgenerations.com/parkour-history/", "title": "Parkour History", "date": "22 August 2014", "publisher": "Parkour Generations", "accessdate": "2 December 2015"}{"citetype": "journal", "date": "July 2006", "title": "Urban Free Flow: A Poetics of Parkour", "url": "http://journal.media-culture.org.au/0607/06-geyh.php", "journal": "M/C Journal", "volume": "9", "issue": "3", "accessdate": "2 December 2015", "last": "Geyh", "first": "Paula"}

The creation of parkour show-reels and documentaries has always been crucial to the spread of parkour, and is common in the parkour community.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}[39] Jump London is a 2003 documentary explaining some of the background of parkour,culminating with Sébastien Foucan, Johann Vigroux, and Jérôme Ben Aoues demonstrating their parkour skills. Jump London changed the presence of parkour in the UK almost overnight and is widely credited for inspiring a new generation of traceurs.{"citetype": "journal", "date": "30 July 2012", "title": "New Media Technologies in Lifestyle Sport", "url": "https://www.academia.edu/1821623", "accessdate": "8 September 2013", "author1": "Gilchrist, Paul", "author2": "Wheaton, Belinda", "conference": "Digital Media Sport: Technology and Power in the Network Society", "editor": "Hutchins/Rowe"} It was followed by Jump Britain in 2005. Both Jump films were shown in over 80 countries exposing the discipline and its philosophy to an unprecedented global audience and are cited by numerous practitioners as their motivation for taking up the discipline.
The Australian version of 60 Minutes broadcast a segment about parkour on 16 September 2007, featuring Foucan and Stephane Vigroux.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=295676", "title": "Go Jump", "last": "Hayes", "first": "Liz", "authorlink": "Liz Hayes", "date": "16 September 2007", "accessdate": "3 January 2008", "work": "[[60 Minutes (Australian TV program)|60 Minutes]]"}
Parkour is not defined by a set of rules or guidelines, which has been particularly attractive to young people, allowing them to explore and engage in the activity on their own terms. It can be easily accepted by all cultures as a means of personal expression and recreation.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2013", "title": "International Review for the Sociology of Sport", "publisher": "SAGE Publications Inc", "page": "5", "last": "Thorpe", "first": "Holly"} For example, in 2010 The New York Times published a short video featuring three young men from the Gaza Strip who were active members of the parkour community.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/video/world/middleeast/1248069141234/palestinian-parkour.html", "title": "Palestinian Parkour", "last": "Sorcher", "first": "Sara", "date": "13 October 2010", "type": "video", "work": "The New York Times"} In 2014, the BBC covered youth parkour participation in Jammu and Kashmir. Zahid Shah founded the Kashmir Freerunning and Parkour Federation, finding hope in the non-violent discipline of parkour.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-30347099/", "title": "Kashmir freerunning: Finding freedom in the art of parkour", "date": "7 December 2014", "accessdate": "1 December 2015"}

Entertainment
Parkour has become a popular element in action sequences, with film directors hiring parkour practitioners as stunt performers. The first director to do so was Luc Besson, for the film Taxi 2 in 1998, followed by Yamakasi in 2001 featuring members of the original Yamakasi group, and its sequel Les fils du vent in 2004. Also in 2004, Besson wrote District 13, another feature film involving advanced parkour chase sequences, starring David Belle and Cyril Raffaelli,{"citetype": "news", "date": "2 January 2007", "title": "Parkour: Leaps of faith", "url": "http://www.dailynews.com/entertainment/ci_4937806", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20070224231820/http://www.dailynews.com/entertainment/ci_4937806", "archivedate": "24 February 2007", "accessdate": "11 December 2007", "first": "Sandra", "last": "Barrera", "newspaper": "[[Los Angeles Daily News]]"}{"citetype": "news", "last1": "Bessaoud", "first1": "Yuba", "last2": "Delmar-Morgan", "first2": "Alex", "date": "9 July 2006", "title": "Focus: Look Mum, watch this!", "url": "http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2262412,00.html", "work": "[[The Times]]", "location": "London", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20080829131418/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2262412,00.html", "archivedate": "29 August 2008", "accessdate": "3 January 2008"} followed by the sequel District 13: Ultimatum in 2009 and remade in English as Brick Mansions in 2014. In 2006 the film Casino Royale featured Sébastien Foucan in a chase taking place early in the movie, sparking renewed media interest in parkour.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/04/16/070416fa_fact_wilkinson?currentPage=all", "title": "No Obstacles", "last": "Wilkinson", "first": "Alec", "date": "16 April 2007", "accessdate": "14 October 2007", "work": "[[The New Yorker]]"} Along with The Bourne Ultimatum (2007), Casino Royale is credited with starting a new wave of Parkour-inspired stunts in Western film and television.{"citetype": "news", "date": "28 August 2009", "title": "Fremantle Pacts to Bring Parkour to TV Screens", "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/televisionNews/idUSTRE57R0OZ20090828", "agency": "[[Reuters]]", "accessdate": "23 September 2009", "first": "Georg", "last": "Szalai"} Parkour was prominent in Live Free or Die Hard (2007),{"citetype": "news", "date": "3 December 2007", "title": "'Look, Ma, no hands' \u2014 or feet", "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/life/lifestyle/2007-12-03-parkour_N.htm", "accessdate": "7 December 2007", "last": "Kornblum", "first": "Janet", "newspaper": "[[USA Today]]"} again with stuntman/actor Cyril Raffaelli, and Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010), choreographed by David Belle.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.emanuellevy.com/comment/prince-of-persia-tackling-stunts-and-parkour-1/", "title": "Prince of Persia: Tackling Stunts and Parkour", "last": "Levy", "first": "Emanuel", "year": "2010", "accessdate": "10 February 2013"} Several films besides Yamakasi are about thieves who use parkour, such as Breaking and Entering (2006),{"citetype": "news", "date": "2 January 2007", "title": "Parkour: Leaps of faith", "url": "http://www.dailynews.com/entertainment/ci_4937806", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20070224231820/http://www.dailynews.com/entertainment/ci_4937806", "archivedate": "24 February 2007", "accessdate": "11 December 2007", "first": "Sandra", "last": "Barrera", "newspaper": "[[Los Angeles Daily News]]"}{"citetype": "news", "last1": "Bessaoud", "first1": "Yuba", "last2": "Delmar-Morgan", "first2": "Alex", "date": "9 July 2006", "title": "Focus: Look Mum, watch this!", "url": "http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2262412,00.html", "work": "[[The Times]]", "location": "London", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20080829131418/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2262412,00.html", "archivedate": "29 August 2008", "accessdate": "3 January 2008"} Run (2013),{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2215457/", "title": "Run (2013)", "accessdate": "13 January 2016", "work": "IMDb"} and Tracers (2015). The 2011 film Freerunner is about eight freerunners racing through a city for survival. Parkour also featured in Dhoom 3 (2013){"citetype": "news", "date": "18 November 2011", "title": "Aamir Khan learns French technique of Parkour", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Aamir-Khan-learns-French-technique-of-Parkour/articleshow/10778399.cms", "accessdate": "24 November 2011", "last": "Lalwani", "first": "Vickey", "newspaper": "[[Mumbai Mirror]]; [[The Times of India]]"}, Bang Bang! (2014) and Aadhi (2018).{"citetype": "news", "date": "25 January 2018", "title": "'Aadhi' packs a punch with parkour", "url": "http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/jeethu-joseph-on-his-film-aadhi-which-introduces-pranav-mohanlal/article22503604.ece", "work": "[[The Hindu]]", "accessdate": "30 January 2018", "last": "George", "first": "Vijay"}
The 2019 Netflix film 6 Underground featured several parkour scenes choreographed and performed by team Storror.{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.looper.com/179374/the-truth-about-those-parkour-scenes-in-6-underground/", "title": "The truth about those parkour scenes in 6 Underground", "last": "Gates", "first": "Christopher", "website": "Looper.com", "language": "en-US", "accessdate": "2020-01-22"}{"citetype": "web", "url": "https://www.metro.us/entertainment/movies/Ben-Hardy-talks-6-underground-and-Michael-Bay", "website": "www.metro.us", "accessdate": "2020-01-22"}
MTV's show Ultimate Parkour Challenge premiered as a one-hour special in October 2009 starring the athletes of the World Freerunning & Parkour Federation. This was followed in May 2010 with a six-episode series of the same name. The athletes were Daniel Ilabaca, Tim Shieff, Ryan Doyle, Michael Turner, Oleg Vorslav, Ben Jenkin, Daniel Arroyo, Pip Andersen and King David. The programme format was a two-part weekly competition in different Southern California locations.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.mtv.com/shows/parkour/series.jhtml", "title": "Ultimate Parkour Challenge", "publisher": "[[MTV]]", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20131207235230/http://www.mtv.com/shows/parkour/series.jhtml", "archivedate": "7 December 2013"}
Actor Stephen Amell learned parkour at Tempest Academy in preparation for his role as Oliver Queen in the television series Arrow,[110] and co-star Caity Lotz is also a practitioner.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.daemonstv.com/2011/07/21/caity-lotz-interview/", "title": "Exclusive Interview: Kick Ass Caity Lotz From MTV's DEATH VALLEY Talks About Zombies, Parcour and Twilight's Jackson Rathbone", "publisher": "Daemon's TV", "accessdate": "27 May 2016"}
Modern video games frequently include aspects of parkour as major game-play elements. The Assassin's Creed series makes heavy use of parkour movement (called freerunning in the game).{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.gamesxtreme.net/x360/game/assassins-creed/review.shtml", "title": "Assassin's Creed (Xbox 360)", "date": "28 November 2007", "accessdate": "11 December 2007", "quote": "It's a good start, an excellent free-roaming adventure with some of the best use of Military training
Although parkour itself grew out of military obstacle-course training,{"citetype": "book", "year": "2011", "title": "Cin\u00e9 Parkour", "isbn": "978-0-9569717-1-5", "ref": "Angel", "last": "Angel", "first": "Julie"}[26] it has become a separate discipline. After the attention that parkour received following the 2006 film Casino Royale, military forces around the world began looking for ways to incorporate elements from parkour into military training. A physical trainer with the Royal Marines trained with parkour practitioners with hopes of introducing some of their techniques to his own students.{"citetype": "news", "date": "12 January 2008", "title": "Freerunning goes to war as marines take tips from EZ, Livewire and Sticky", "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/jan/12/military.uknews4", "work": "The Guardian", "location": "London", "accessdate": "9 August 2009", "first": "Robert", "last": "Booth"} Colorado Parkour began a project to introduce elements from parkour into the U.S. military{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.coloradoparkour.com/projects.html", "title": "Projects", "publisher": "Colorado Parkour", "accessdate": "9 August 2009"} and one San Diego staff sergeant trained US Marines in parkour.{"citetype": "web", "url": "http://www.miramar.usmc.mil/newspage175.htm", "title": "Parkour: Getting over the wall", "date": "23 January 2009", "publisher": "US Marine Corps", "accessdate": "9 August 2009", "archiveurl": "https://web.archive.org/web/20090414060418/http://www.miramar.usmc.mil/newspage175.htm", "archivedate": "14 April 2009"}

Derivative terminologies and disciplines
In September 2003, Mike Christie's documentary Jump London, starring Sébastien Foucan, was released. In the documentary, the term "freerunning" was used as an attempt to translate "parkour", in order to make it more appealing to the English-speaking audience.[128] Foucan decided to keep using the term "freerunning" to describe his discipline, to distinguish it from David Belle's methods.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2008", "title": "Free Running", "pages": "8\u20139", "isbn": "978-1-56975-652-2", "last": "Foucan", "first": "S\u00e9bastien", "authorlink": "S\u00e9bastien Foucan"}[130]
The remaining seven Yamakasi members continued to use the term "l'art du déplacement", also not wanting to associate it too closely with parkour. Similar to Sébastien's freerunning, l'art du déplacement was less about the hard discipline from the original Yamakasi group, more a participatory approach focused on making the teaching more accessible. David Belle kept the term "parkour", saying the group contributed to the development of it, but that his father was the source of his motivation, who had verbally communicated this method only to him.[130]
Both parkour and freerunning encompass the ideas of overcoming obstacles and self-expression; in freerunning, the greater emphasis is on self-expression.{"citetype": "book", "year": "2008", "title": "Free Running", "pages": "8\u20139", "isbn": "978-1-56975-652-2", "last": "Foucan", "first": "S\u00e9bastien", "authorlink": "S\u00e9bastien Foucan"} Although the differences between the disciplines are often hard to discern, practitioners tend to aspire to parkour and describe themselves as traceurs rather than as freerunners.{"citetype": "journal", "doi ": "10.1111/j.1540-6040.2012.01406.x", "title ": "Parkour, the Affective Appropriation of Urban Space, and the Real/Virtual Dialectic", "journal ": "City & Community", "volume ": "11", "issue ": "3", "pages ": "229\u2013253", "year ": "2012", "last1 ": "Kidder", "first1 ": "J. L.", "citeseerx ": "10.1.1.645.395"}
